sections.heading: Performance-Based Contracting Toolkit: Digital Hypertension Management Solutions

steps.description:
This toolkit focuses on digital hypertension management solutions, drawing on findings from PHTI's Digital Hypertension Management Solutions Health Technology Assessment and PHTI's Performance-Based Contracting Playbook.

What this toolkit does:

Helps purchasers and digital health vendors establish clear, evidence-based contract terms that align payment with improvements in blood pressure control and related outcomes.

First, you will determine the design of the payment model. Next, you will determine the inputs for outcome measures, which include eligibility criteria, meaningful engagement criteria, and performance metrics. Finally, you will select operational components, which include engagement approach, data sharing commitments, and administrative terms, to include in your contracts.

A few notes before you continue:

  • This toolkit helps you navigate key contracting decisions for performance-based contracts. It does not create a binding legal contract.
  • These toolkits do not address pricing—a critical lever for driving impact in performance-based contracts. Purchasers and vendors are encouraged to consult PHTI’s assessment reports and budget impact models as resources to guide pricing conversations.
  • Toolkit responses are anonymous. We do not gather or store any data about you, your organization, or your selections.

The content of this playbook/report and its associated toolkits has been prepared by PHTI for informational purposes and does not constitute legal, medical, clinical or other professional advice. PHTI cannot make any guarantees or warranties regarding results from the use of such content. The content is not intended to replace thoughtful customization and drafting addressing an organization’s specific objectives and circumstances. All companies, specific products or case studies mentioned are for explanatory purposes only.

Prefer to skip the interactive toolkit? Download the digital hypertension management solutions toolkit with PHTI's recommended selections.

tooltipDrawer.label: Learn more about payment models.
tooltipDrawer.text:
About Payment Models

A performance-based contract structures your payments to reward outcomes while minimizing administrative burden, avoiding perverse incentives, and balancing accountability with budget predictability.

steps.heading: Select the payment model(s) for the contract.
steps.description:
There are multiple ways to structure your payment. Many performance-based contracts today use a clawback model, in which vendors are paid up front, with the understanding that funds will be returned if previously agreed-upon performance guarantees are missed. In practice, though, clawbacks are rarely enforced as written. Purchasers report that this undermines accountability and creates friction with vendors, particularly at the end of a contract.

A stronger alternative is a two-stream payment model that separates fees for engaged members from performance payments—vendors receive a lower base fee tied to meaningful engagement, with the performance component withheld until outcomes are achieved. This approach maintains some vendor cash flow while withholding part of the fees for demonstrated results.

PHTI recommends tying a majority of contract value to performance payment.
steps.instructions: Recommended values are pre-filled. Percentages must sum to 100%.

tooltip.text: PEMPM: Monthly payment for each member meeting meaningful engagement criteria (see section 3 - Engagement Criteria).
Additional payment based on achievement of selected performance measure(s) (see section 4 - Performance metrics).

options.label: Shared savings

tooltip.text: Shared savings is the calculation of  the difference between actual healthcare spending for the engaged population compared to their expected spending. The savings of the avoided costs are then split between the purchaser and vendor. Should only be pursued by purchasers who are able to analyze and validate statistically valid cost savings results, either in-house or through a third-party vendor.

options.note:
PHTI recognizes that performance-based contracts include maintenance or follow-on periods to support sustained clinical outcomes when the evidence base supports it and at an appropriate cost. These periods should be contracted at a lower price point, with performance expectations tailored to member status at the maintenance period baseline. For members that remain above clinical thresholds at the beginning of the maintenance period, performance payment should be tied to improvement and achievement of control. For members already in control, performance payment should be tied to sustaining status and preventing regression.

Contracting tips:

Per engaged member per month (PEMPM)

  • Consider adding a time limit for PEMPM payments for a given individual (e.g., until 4 quarters of blood pressure control)
  • Consider structuring PEMPM payments as a fixed, upfront fee that is tiered by the number of eligible members to simplify administration.

Performance payment

  • To define the maximum possible performance payment, utilize the anticipated total PEMPM payment for members who exceed agreed-upon program tenure.

Shared savings

  • Define the time frame for calculating shared savings. This will typically be longer than the annual reconciliation for the performance payment (e.g., 3 years).
  • Subtract the payments made for PEMPM and performance payments during the shared savings measurement period to calculate the total savings as this reflects savings already shared with the vendor.

tooltipDrawer.label: About eligible population.
tooltipDrawer.text:
About Eligibility Population

Eligibility criteria determine which plan members may engage with the solution and have their outcomes measured. Eligibility typically includes clinical criteria, demographics, or utilization history.

The inclusion and exclusion criteria define the total population of eligible members who may engage with the solution. Narrowing the eligibility will limit the number of individuals who may be included in the denominator and the numerator.

Contracting tip:

  • Include clause allowing digital health solution vendor to update the exclusion criteria based on medical contraindications.
  • Specify timing for when exclusion criteria adjustments can be made to the contract.

steps.heading: Payment Model Inputs
steps.description:
The following section details the inputs required to define the eligible population and calculate outcomes measures. The selections for each of these components will impact the threshold for PEMPM payments as well as the equation for calculating performance withholds.

Performance Payment Calculation:

  • Numerator: For cohort in the denominator, number of eligible members who meet the performance threshold for the measure of interest.
  • Denominator: Total eligible members who meet the meaningful engagement definition for duration of program tenure requirement.

steps.heading: Select the members eligible to use the solution.

options.label: All members with a diagnosis of hypertension
options.description:
• Those with a documented diagnosis or history of stage 1 hypertension or stage 2 hypertension, or
  • Those on hypertension prescription medication with a physician-conducted blood pressure reading that resulted in measurement equal to stage 1 or stage 2 hypertension

options.label: Those with a recent emergency department visit or inpatient discharge

tooltip.text: HEDIS metrics typically exclude those older than 85 years and younger than 18 years.

tooltipDrawer.label: About engagement criteria.
tooltipDrawer.text:
Clear, meaningful engagement thresholds help limit payment to members who are meaningfully engaged with the solution and most likely to experience a clinical impact. While there are many common engagement metrics, not all are considered meaningful.

In the two-payment stream model, the definition of meaningful engagement directly impacts the size of the payments made to the vendor. A looser definition of engagement will create a larger PEMPM payment and will increase the number of individuals whose clinical outcomes are considered for the performance payment.

Contracting tip:

  • Explicitly define ‘transaction’ (e.g., blood pressure recording) and prioritize member-initiated and clinically significant interactions.
  • Define the maximum days (e.g., 15) for capturing baseline blood pressure reading, considering operational workflows.

steps.heading: Define engagement criteria for the contract.
steps.description:
Currently the main definitions of engagement in use today include metrics such as app logins, email opens, and an engagement index. Purchasers increasingly indicate that they prefer more meaningful engagement metrics, especially as these metrics serve as the basis for PEMPM payments and performance payment calculations. PHTI’s recommended definitions focus on engagement milestones that are correlated with clinical impact.

PHTI recommends members meet 3 criteria to be considered meaningfully engaged. Criteria 1 and 2 are required.

Recommended values are pre-filled.

options.label: Criteria 1: Member completes onboarding, initial assessment, or first visit.

tooltip.text: Engagement tied to clinician interaction, including sessions, coaching calls, messages.

options.label: Criteria 2: Baseline physician or member blood pressure readings captured within __ days before or after program start, as defined above.
Criteria 3: At least __ member-initiated transactions with program per month for __ months.

tooltip.text: Improvement in blood pressure can typically be expected within 3 months.

tooltipDrawer.label: About performance metrics.
tooltipDrawer.text:
Select validated, feasible measures–favoring biomarker-based outcomes and clinically accepted instruments–and determine the time horizon for impact.

PHTI recommends tying all or the majority of the performance payment to attainment of blood pressure control.

Contracting tip:

  • Blood Pressure Control
    • Specify the allowable time frame for collecting a member’s final measurement that is used to calculate the change as compared to baseline, in order to be included in the performance payment calculation.
    • Use HEDIS guidelines for acceptable and not acceptable blood pressure readings. Vendors may need to educate patients.
  • Medication Adherence
    • Define minimum member months required for valid sample size (e.g., at least 50 participants in program for 60 days).
    • Exclude members not prescribed medication within 60 days of enrollment.

steps.heading: Select which performance metric(s) should be tied to the performance payment.
steps.description:
NCQA’s HEDIS measure BPC-E (Blood Pressure Control for Patients with Hypertension) is widely accepted and calculated for quality improvement programs. This measure assesses the percent of individuals in a defined population whose blood pressure is controlled below a universal threshold (<140/90). PHTI recommends it as the preferred option for performance measure targets.

Some purchasers and vendors may elect to measure absolute change in systolic blood pressure (SBP) to capture clinical improvement across the full risk spectrum. Using the SBP measure allows contracts to reward meaningful improvements among patients with more severe baseline hypertension who do not fall below the threshold at the end of the measurement period, while also recognizing improvements among patients who begin below the threshold but experience further blood pressure reductions. This approach limits rewards for small changes concentrated around the control cutoff (e.g., just above to just below <140/90) and instead ties payment to improvement in average SBP across the cohort.

Recommended values are pre-filled. Percentages must sum to 100%.

If focusing on blood pressure control, set to 100%. If incorporating medication adherence, select the percentage of the total performance payment that will be tied to each.

tooltip.text: PHTI recommends contracts include a performance payment tied to improvements in blood pressure. This can be measured either via the HEDIS measure (BPC-E) or via absolute change in average SBP across the population, not both.

options.label: HEDIS Blood Pressure Control for Patients with Hypertension (BPC-E)

tooltip.text: The percentage of members 18–85 years of age who had a diagnosis of hypertension (HTN) and whose most recent blood pressure (BP) was <140/90 mm Hg. Source: HEDIS MY 2025.
For members who exceed agreed-upon program tenure, change in systolic BP relative to target (e.g., >5 mmHg).
Percent of members who have >= 1 fill/dispense with >80% proportion of days covered (PDC), verified by pharmacy claims or digital pharmacy partners, among those prescribed.

steps.heading: Confirm desired program tenure for inclusion in the performance payment.
steps.description:
Improvement in hypertension, including prescription medications, can be expected to yield results within 6 months: From PHTI’s Digital Hypertension Management Solutions Health Technology Assessment, studies show large reductions in systolic blood pressure as early as three months, with most reductions accruing by six months. At six months, digital solution users had a statistically significant improvement in self-reported medication adherence, whereas patients receiving usual care did not.

Recommended values are pre-filled.

tooltipDrawer.label: About engagement approaches.
tooltipDrawer.text:
Engagement approaches establish clear parameters for how vendors may contact and interact with members to promote engagement with the solution.

Purchasers may seek to limit outreach frequency, require member consent or opt-in, and specify permissible channels (e.g., text, phone, mailer) to protect member trust and prevent over communication. Vendors value flexibility to reach members through multiple touch points and may need to tailor outreach strategies to different populations. This repeated, multimodal contact can be important to drive engagement and outcomes for some solutions.

options.label: Governance Alignment: Vendor will adhere to the purchaser’s existing governance processes for member communications (e.g., prior review committees, compliance protocols) and will not initiate outreach outside of those processes without written approval.

Material Review & Approval: Vendor will submit all co-branded and company-branded outreach and education materials for purchaser approval prior to use (co-branded materials are generally preferred and shown to improve engagement). Purchaser will approve or propose modifications within __ days of submission.

Revisions & Updates: Any revisions to previously approved materials (including templates, scripts, and digital content) must be resubmitted for purchaser review and approval within __ days before deployment.

Outreach Parameters: Purchaser and vendor will agree in advance on the minimum or maximum number, frequency, and type of outreach attempts (e.g., SMS, email, phone) to optimize engagement while minimizing member abrasion. Any deviation requires prior purchaser approval.
Compliance & Reporting: Vendor will track all member outreach against agreed guidelines and share reporting (frequency, channel, response rates, opt-outs) with the purchaser at agreed intervals.

Member Experience Protections: Outreach must comply with applicable laws and regulations (e.g., TCPA, HIPAA) and avoid high-frequency or intrusive tactics. Vendor will promptly address purchaser concerns about member complaints or abrasion.

tooltipDrawer.label: About data sharing commitments.
tooltipDrawer.text:
Reliable performance measurement is foundational to performance-based contracting. To assess whether a solution is driving clinical or financial impact, purchasers and vendors need access to timely, high-quality data and the analytic capacity to interpret them in a timely manner.

Contracting tip:

  • For all data file sharing, determine cadence and format for sharing prior to contracting. Consider including template reports in the contract to ensure file readability.
  • Purchasers commit to active list management, including monthly deletions, corrections, and additions.
  • Purchaser submits monthly list in machine readable format with members that meet eligibility criteria. Eligibility file should include full population to avoid claims lag post-diagnosis. Pre-determine select data fields to include in the file (e.g., plan ID, name, address, demographics).
  • Include purchaser audit rights for vendor data in contract.
  • For performance payments based on medication adherence, pharmacy claims file may be required to determine performance metrics. Detail necessary data from pharmacy benefit managers (PBMs) and incorporate any data sharing agreements prior to contracting.

steps.heading: Select which data sharing commitments should be included in the contract.

fields.label: Data sharing format (from purchaser to vendor)

tooltip.text: Supports identification of eligible population, and attribution. Purchasers may consider summary data in lieu of raw claims files.

options.label: Inpatient admission and/or ED visit data from Admission, Discharge, Transfer (ADT) data feeds

tooltip.text: Individuals may be more primed for behavior change after an acute event, supporting the need for real-time data for risk stratification and high-risk member identification.
Supports clinical baselines and ending measures.

fields.label: Data sharing format (from vendor to purchaser)

options.label: Baseline blood pressure for each member

tooltip.text: e.g., measures proximate to enrollment and last measurement of the performance period.
For members excluded for clinical reasons, share report of documented reasons.

options.label: Data required to feed into data warehouse/third party data management resource

tooltipDrawer.label: About administrative terms.
tooltipDrawer.text:
Contracting tip:

  • Require a minimum number of meaningfully engaged patients to trigger performance payment. If minimum is not met, suggest no performance payment.
  • Incorporate terms around pro-rating bonuses if contract is terminated early or not renewed.

steps.heading: Select Administrative Terms: Reconciliation
steps.description:
The timeline required to observe meaningful improvements in clinical outcomes or reductions in total cost of care frequently exceeds the duration of most purchaser-vendor contracts.

Purchasers should consider availability of resources required to calculate performance payments prior to establishing bonus determination deadline.

Recommended values are pre-filled.

options.label: One year measurement period, beginning when minimum enrollment is achieved for __ months

tooltip.text: Improvement in hypertension, including prescription medications, can be expected to yield results within 6 months, per PHTI’s Digital Hypertension Management Solutions Health Technology Assessment.
Populated based on minimum program tenure selection in Decision 4: Performance Metrics.

options.label: Bonuses determined within a __-month period following __ months post-measurement period

tooltip.text: Suggest 3 months to ensure time for claims run-out.

steps.heading: Select Administrative Terms: Duration and Renewal

options.label: __-year initial term, with fixed price throughout term

tooltip.text:
Cause for termination may include:

  • Lack of critical mass of members meeting meaningful engagement criteria
  • Lack of critical mass of members meeting program tenure for performance payment eligibility

options.label: Billing Frequency
options.note: Most purchasers will elect quarterly PEMPM payments and annual performance payments. In cases where high churn exists among members, purchasers may prefer to reconcile performance payments on a quarterly basis.

options.label: Per engaged member per month (PEMPM) payments billing frequency
